title: Will Claire McCaskill (D-MO) be re-elected this November?
preds: I'm revising upward.  Indications area there is a blue wave coming and McCaskill is riding it.
New high quality polls says she is now quite behind
Affirming. Mcaskill will defy the outside view and lose
+6% Back on 538 model, pleased to see 2 new polls that have McCaskill winning and are quality polls as per 538 ratings.

I have much skepticism of the polls so I'm going high for 2 reasons that have to do with an expectation of turnout.
1) Missouri voters defeated a GOP-backed 'right to work' law by a 2 to 1 margin in August. . .this is a big deal. 
2) Missouri's minimum wage is $7.85 per hour, but an initiative petition on the November ballot would raise it to $12 per hour.
Hawley supports “Right to Work” laws and opposed Proposition A; McCaskill opposes “Right to Work” and endorsed Proposition A. Hawley does not support the minimum wage initiative.
This should help turnout for McCaskill.
Chance decreased due to direction and latest number of polls.

Up from prediction last week. At that time I thought Mccaskil had blown out. Instead,it appears that she is now a slight
Underdog...in the newest polls... not behind by more than the polls estimated error.
She's now apparently running an ad that says she's "not one of those crazy Democrats" ( https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/24/politics/claire-mccaskill-crazy-democrats/index.html ).
Outside view always favored mccaskill, but polls indicate it’s slipping away for her. First time I’ve dropped below 50% odds for her

-10% due to polling trends and the tendency of 538 model to lag, I'm going to step ahead of their lag curve and drop Claire's chances. The last poll is the first in weeks, and it is paid for by the dem and even it show her losing.  I will return to 538's model in a week or so.
Is the Attorney General Josh Hawley believable and likeable? Is healthcare a big issue in Missouri? I don't know, hence the questions.

If I'm right that Sen. Mccaskill is done, it will not be fore changing her stand on K or 2A issues but for having the temerity to try to have it both ways on the down low in the show me state. She'd have fared better by taking a strong stance either way and declaring it.
I don't know how I missed this one. Weighing in late.
I see most predictions are old. MacCaskill is tanking
1st the SCOTUS vote and now her 2A STAND - SHE'S GIVING IT AWAY.
Deviating -5% from 538m based on recent polls with good MoE. I will hop back on 538 once I see another poll that has +3 spread or better for Dem.
RCP average has Hawley up 0.3%, but 538 gives her 49.5%.

Note to self. Taking senate races directly from 538 as their methodology is identical to mine but without the hassle of poll bias adjustment. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/missouri/#deluxe
Shifting by weighing my forecast more closely to 538 than predictit.
SO AFP in Arkansas has called off its phone banks working on Missouri and shifted to Colorado. THey think Claire is done.
She is a good fit for Missouri and a likeable politician. Plus she is lucky and finds a way to pull ot out.
Her odds were much lower till July (lean Republican race) and then she's managed to hold steady (toss up) and has been considered "lean Democrat"now.

Much as it pains me to do so, I am dropping 10 points because polls are showing a pretty tight race. McCaskill has a history of winning tight races against weak opponents so I still think she pulls it off.

Rarely is a campaign this beset by attacks and out spent by outsiders. I Don't lend my support to programs that agitate from outside a states borders but many of my Compatriots (Q secret word of the day) do not have that hesitation.

Democratic incumbent Sen. Claire McCaskill leads Republican challenger Josh Hawley by 4 percentage points among likely voters when third party candidates are included, according to an NBC News/Marist poll released Tuesday.
McCaskill’s edge among likely voters falls within the poll’s margin of error, signaling a tight contest in one of this year’s most important Senate races.
President Trump’s aggressive trade policy hasn’t resonated with Missouri voters, according to the poll. Only 28 percent of likely voters believe tariffs protect jobs and help the economy.
Energized Democratic base vs. Lower (midterm) turnout by Republican base

248 from 122 @0.52 
Was 95 now back to 85 (opening bet on March 15th).
Dropping to 51%. I see MO & NV as fundamentally same: incumbent out of step with prevailing sentiment in his or her state and behind in the polls w 2 months to go.

I'm calling this a true toss-up. McCaskill is liked in St. Louis and Kansas City, as well as various other smaller urban areas, but large amounts of dark money are going Hawley's way, and Missouri has only gotten redder over the last few decades.
AFP Arkansas and surrounding states are full steam on the phone banks calling into Missouri. There is a lot going into knocking her out of there.

Mid Aug poll released by KSHB shows McCaskill and Hawley in "statistical" tie... it was conducted by TJP Strategies, a Dem-ish consulting firm... sampling error margin of plus or minus 2.3 percentage "points..."

The Kochs are spending more than 2 million dollars on campaign adds over the course of the next few months against McCaskill.  As a result, I have lowered the odds.  But given her history and given Trump's increasing instability I think McCaskill will still win by a narrow margin.  She is the incumbent and that matters.  That should give her the edge.
Reducing 3%. Outside view still favors McCaskill, but inside view (polls) looking bad.
Trailing-to-even in the polls when you're an incumbent, in a year where your party should do well, is a bad sign.
She seems to be in a very vulnerable position.
~ 10% more GOP voters in the primaries even when Proposition A was on the ballot.

Seriously, what's up with the bulk of people here not even attempting to make serious predictions but just engaging in 'political hack playtime'?
If you're so in the bag for one party that you actually end up looking at everything they do through the lens of strategy rather than real world consequences, you have completely failed as a steward of our Republic.

If she loses, it's all because those evil Russians, Daily Beast forensic analysis reveals. Daily Beast forensic analysis! https://www.thedailybeast.com/russian-hackers-new-target-a-vulnerable-democratic-senator
"The hackers sent forged notification emails." Hmm, I get about half a dozen of those daily. A sure sign of GRU operation against me!

She may get a big bump if her team is able to exploit the veracity of the content suggesting  foreign interests "meddling" to defeat her as indicated in this Daily Beast article... link here https://www.thedailybeast.com/russian-hackers-new-target-a-vulnerable-democratic-senator?utm_campaign=newsletter270718&utm_source=sendpulse&utm_medium=email
Dropping down given her inherent vulnerability, the Supreme Court situation, & recent polls highlighted by @dcm
backing down from standard rate for Incumbents due to TV AD campaign backed by 1/2 million in out =side money highlighting her voting record.
{Don't mind me, just clearin' my list}
Affirming as McCaskill still leading in polls: https://www.270towin.com/2018-senate-polls/missouri/ and power of incumbency.

While there is no new news or polls, a couple of factors influence my slight downgrade (of 1%):
- Trump job approval has not tanked significantly, despite the fierce attack on the illegal immigrants' children issue. It does decrease, but his job disapproval rating surprisingly has decreased to 52%. 
- In April poll, Trump has job approval of 55% in MO, so it may be risky for McCaskill to play anti-Trump card
- Her main challenger Hawley  is relatively unknown, but scandal around the R-Governor may boost his  name recognition. The scandal didn't tank Hawley despite great effort by McCaskill to tie Hawley with the disgraced governor. Early August Primary may boost even more Hawley's name recognition. 
- Once Hawley clears the Primary hurdle, more money will pour into his campaign since McCaskill is considered the most vulnerable among tossup races. If McCaskill remains in the Senate, the Democrats would likely flip the Senate by more than 4 seats. But if Blue Wave fizzles, McCaskill would be the first peg to fall.
If the conversation moves to switching the senate and approving the justice that President Trump appoints to replace Justice Kennedy, then Hawley could see an improvement.
Senator McCaskill has a slight edge in a tight race, so I'm giving her a greater than 50% chance to prevail.
Is the graph broken? Stuck at 65%
Greitens being out helps a bit more to give her a better chance.
She should get a healthy bump considering how the GOP has behaved during the debacle involving now ex-governor Eric Greitens,  and add to that women who lean GOP.
Affirming. Despite her uphill battle if her opponent gets his house in order
Senator McCaskill will probably hang onto to her seat in a likely Democratic wave election. Her chances will increase if a hard right candidate wins the Republican nomination,
This election is a toss up.  So I am going with the theory:  All things being equal party affiliation will win the day.  Missouri is a Red state.

The direction of the polls isn't quite what McCaskill hopes for, the congressional generic ballot polls has a red shift, the President's poll goes up.
It is still a long way to go before November and bombs could still be dropped. But it won't cut it for a sitting Dem Senator to have only 1 point ahead this far out from November. And all that while her opponent supposedly was dealt with a bad hand (the GOP governor's scandal).

upping my previous forecast by 5 because of the great article that @acohen shared on Politico about how Greiten is stifling Missouri GOP: https://www.politico.com/story/2018/04/23/mccaskill-missouri-greitens-republicans-senate-545393
She is lucky to get the such hapless candidates opposing here.
Going up a few points because of an article I recently read, see link.
Long history with constituents. Veterans and military like her.
Her team must sense trouble...she has equivocated or moderated on multiple issues and speaks in caveats as of late...edging down ever so slowly...
Josh Hawley is too young and the wrong candidate at the wrong time.

Josh Hawley is joining Claire McCaskill in calling for the resignation of Governor Greitens. 
How he handles this distancing from Greitens as well as how he continues to investigate Geritens' charity as Attorney General will be important in the race.
Although she has been thought to have a weak grip on her seat, incumbents usually win.
I think the Governors problems (indicted for privacy invasion in #metoo case) is going to affect a good turn out for Claire.
RePublicans donâ€™t have a named candidate to go up against her and they tend to screw up like Todd Akin did
Obama did his first fundraiser. And it was in Hollywood. Missouri? Hollywood? No wonder the flyover state hates the Dems so much.
Hawley is going after Google!  Pick your battles carefully.

Although it will be a tough fight, the current wave carrying Democratic candidates forward should carry her through as well.  She has worked hard for her constituents and has maintained a high profile (with demonstrated rationality) while serving as Senator.

Wave election enthusiasm +
Off year election -
Bannon and mainstream republicans agree on Hawley -
No creditable 3rd party candidate - tactic MacCaskill has used 3 times before -
People in Missouri have turned against mcKaskill

McCaskill is a survivor and knows her state well. More generally, this is shaping up to be a wave year which should protect her and while its hard to find much polling, trump seems to be barely above water in the state.

I think that she will finally be voted out, after barely winning the last two election cycles. However, if a late spurt by a different opponent materializes, then I would reverse the prediction; it would be another dirty tricks event by the McCaskill campaign. Each of the last two cycles, there was a sudden spurt by a secondary opponent in the Republican primary that allowed for a candidate with some questionable views to be the party's nominee, and that person was an easy target for McCaskill to defeat.
Missouri has become a vehement Red State and Claire McCaskill had a hard time winning in 2012 against a flawed GOP candidate.

Because Senator Claire McCaskill is the incumbent Senator, she is significantly more likely to be reelected because of the incumbency advantage. As such, I believe there is a high probability that Senator McCaskill will be reelected.
Slim favorite, because she is a good campaigner and 2018 might be shaping up as a wave election. She has some headwinds, mainly related to how Missouri has voted in recent years.
Missourians are very fed up with McCaskill
Prevailing confusion about ideologies could allow existing players to continue their streak
The election will fill the Class 1 Senate seat held by Claire McCaskill (D). She was first elected in 2006.

3rd candidate makes it even trickier. Seems she wasn't going that well, but I just can't get past the incumbency record. Until there is a huge cleanout and the reliable stat gets trashed you just can't go against the grain.

1) 82% Senate Incumbent Victory rate over last 27 election cycles (past 54 years). https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/reelect.php & http://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/incumbent-reelection-rates-higher-than-average-in-2016/
2) 3x most recent polls basically show dead heat https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/mo/missouri_senate_hawley_vs_mccaskill-6280.html
3) MO's been trending red lately, but Republican's situation starting to look bad after PA-18
4) Opposition Party Incumbent Senators running in mid term when POTUS won their state: 39/42 have won going back to 1982. 93% https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-the-2018-senate-elections-are-looking-bad-for-both-parties/
5) Multiple outside views heavily favor McCaskill. Going to have to favor McCaskill as well but will continue to monitor as a race that polls indicate is this close could change on a dime.

Expected to be a close race. there is also a 3rd party candidate, Craig O'Dear who could take votes from both McCaskill and Hawley however, O'Dear is a lifelong Republican. Here's one take on it: http://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-senate-midterm-elections-778794
Trump lost 20 points in PA yesterday when his Republican stand in lost in a near dead heat.  Missouri is equally tough and McCaskill is a stronger candidate.
The odds are in the “Probability Not” category I’d believe.
